posts.name: Brayden DeGraff
posts.cooked: Hi, so my team and I are currently using grey connectors for some of the CAN bus wires. Some of these wires had to be cut and spliced together because they weren’t long enough, and they are now shorting. We’ve tried different wires and connectors, but it still shorts out. We’ve noticed that the wires only short when plugged into the connector. The name of the connector is Eugiichr Lever Wire Connectors. Has anyone experienced a similar issue and found a solution?

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: A picture would be good. It could be the connector you are using is designed to be a common rail and is not a dual circuit device.

posts.name: Brayden DeGraff
posts.cooked: Hi I just discovered the name of the connector is Eugiichr Lever Wire Connectors

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Lever connectors have different styles ment to join different types of circuits and you may be using the wrong type.

A picture would be helpful for us to let you know if you need a different style or if the ones you have should be working and you should look at a different device or perform other troubleshooting steps.

posts.name: Brayden DeGraff
posts.cooked: I am not currently with robot I am on my way to it right now but this is the best picture I have of it currently

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Are all of them this style? Single wire in, single wire out in-line style?

Those would not cause a “short” to another separate/different circuit unless there was some other manufacturing/installation fault like wire strands sticking out of 2 nearby each other and they were touching.

When you say you have a CAN bus short, what is the resistance measured on a volt-ohm meter or digital multi meter between the green and yellow wires? It should be ~60ohms.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
Unplug the thing at the start of your CAN bus (usually the rio) and the thing at the end of your CAN bus (usually a PDH or a resistor).

Put a multimeter into its “ohm” mode.

Touch the meter’s probes to the two dangling yellow wires you made in step 1. It should say 0 ohms. Under 10 ohms is probably okay if you’re using those lever connectors.

Repeat step 3 with the green wire.

Repeat step 3, but probing a green wire at one end and a yellow wire at the other end. If should say infinity or -1 or something like that.

Repeat step 3, but probing the other green wire at one end and the other yellow wire at the other end. Again, infinity or -1 or whatever.

If you do step 3 and you don’t get < 10 ohms, then there’s a bad connection somewhere in your yellow wire path.

Ditto for step 4 / green wire.

If the meter sees a resistance in steps 5 and/or 6, your yellow and green wires are getting connected to each other somewhere.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Check that you don’t have the CAN wires running over a sharp metal edge.

We did the tests that @evanperryg described and found that we had good connections for the CAN wires but we were not getting any signal. We found that one of the CAN wires showed continuity to the chassis. After more investigation, we found insulation on the CAN wire that had been cut through by a sharp edge on the chassis where the zip ties were very tight.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
Yep, this is excellent advice as well. Check for continuity to your robot’s frame. Try probing a few different places on your frame, too - it can make a surprising difference.

@Brayden135 a few more pieces of advice:

Make sure nobody put the green and yellow wires into a single lever connector together. It sounds funny, but it happens to the best of us.

If you un-twisted the CAN wires, twist them back together again. Based on your picture, it looks like you left them twisted, which is good. The twisty-ness of CAN wires is actually important to making CAN work properly. If your first instinct is to ask “why?” consider taking AP Physics C if your school offers it.

Also, make sure your PDH and RIO are at opposite ends of your CAN bus, and make sure the PDH ’s “TERM” switch is set to “ON.” If the PDH absolutely CAN ’T (heh) be at the opposite end of the bus from your RIO, you will need to get a 120 ohm resistor and attach it to the last pair of wires in your CAN bus. If your lever connectors are decent, you should actually be able to use them to attach the resistor to the CAN wires.

If you’re using a CTRE CANivore, consider soldering its CAN bus instead of using lever connectors. Even the name-brand WAGO lever connectors can cause trouble for the CANivore’s higher-speed bus.
